section.title: Intro to Solving Systems, Gaussian Elimination

subsection.title: Existence and Uniqueness
subsection.p:
When solving a system, we have two main questions:
Existence. Does the system have at least one solution?
Uniqueness. If the system has a solution, is it unique? Or, is there more than one solution?

subsection.title: Triangular Systems, Back-Substitution
subsection.p: Some systems are particularly simple to solve.
Systems with this staircase form are called triangular. More precisely,
subsection.definition: A linear system is triangular if the last equation has at most 1 variable, the 2nd-last has at most 2 variables, the 3rd-last has at most 3 variables, etc.
subsection.p: Triangular systems can be solved using this simple technique, called back-substitution. This technique can be used for any triangular system to solve for the value of each variable.

subsection.title: Gaussian Elimination, Elementary Operations
subsection.p: Gaussian elimination is a procedure, or algorithm, to transform a system of linear equations to triangular form, making it much easier to solve. Broadly, it involves combining equations of a system in various ways. Each step replaces the current system with another somewhat simpler system, without changing the solution set. In other words, the simpler system is equivalent to the original system, in that the simpler system has the same solution set as the original system. After the system is converted into triangular form, solving this resulting system gives the solution to the original system.
subsection.definition:
Elementary operations Denote equation i by E_i. Then, the elementary operations are,
Interchange. Interchange the order of two equations in the system, E_1 \leftrightarrow E_j.
Scaling. Multiply (or divide) an equation by a non-zero real number, kE_i \rightarrow E_i.
Replacement. Add to one equation a multiple of another equation, E_i + kE_j \rightarrow E_i.
subsection.p: The fact that these elementary operations do not change the solution set of the system is crucial, and it somewhat subtle, and will be explained after an example.

section.subsection:
Remark on Elementary Operations
A crucial property of elementary operations is that applying them does not change the solution set of the system. More precisely, if an elementary operation transforms system 1 into system 2, then system 1 and system 2 have the same solution set.
First, interchanging two equations E_i \leftrightarrow E_j, i.e. rearranging the order of the equations, clearly does not affect the solutions of those two equations, and so doesn't affect the solution set of the system.
Also, multiplying an equation E_i by a non-zero constant k does not change the solutions of that equation, as any solution of E_i is also a solution of kE_i, and vise versa. This is true as long as k \neq 0, as if k = 0, then 0 \cdot K_i is just the equation 0 = 0 for which any tuple will be a solution.
Finally, consider adding a multiple of an equation to another equation, E_i + kE_j \rightarrow E_i. Let (x_1, \dots, x_n) be a solution to the original system. Then, it is a solution of E_i and E_j. From before, it is also a solution to kE_j. This implies that (x_1, \dots, x_n) is a solution to the sum E_i + kE_j.
Then, it follows that any sequence of these operations will not change the solution set of the system.

subsection.title: Solving Systems of Two Equations in Two Variables
subsection.p:
Consider a system of two equations in two unknowns,
a x_1 + b x_2 \amp = y_1 c x_1 + d x_2 \amp = y_2
Here, we have relabelled variables for simplicity. The variables here are x_1 and x_2, and the coefficients are a, b, c, d, y_1, y_2. Using elimination, we can solve this system. For example, to eliminate x_1 in the second equation, subtract c times the first equation to a times the second equation. The resulting equation is,
(ad - bc) x_2 = a y_2 - c y_1
Then, we can solve for x_2 by dividing both sides by ad - bc,
x_2 = \frac{a}{ad - bc} y_2 - \frac{c}{ad - bc} y_1
Similarly, starting from the original system,
a x_1 + b x_2 \amp = y_1 c x_1 + d x_2 \amp = y_2
We can eliminate x_2 in the second equation by subtracting d times the first equation from b times the second equation. The resulting equation is,
(ad - bc) x_1 = d y_1 - b y_2
Then, similarly, solving for x_1,
x_1 = \frac{d}{ad - bc} y_1 - \frac{b}{ad - bc} y_2
Thus, the solution is,
(x,y) = \brac{\frac{d}{ad - bc} y_1 - \frac{b}{ad - bc} y_2, \frac{a}{ad - bc} y_2 - \frac{c}{ad - bc} y_1}
For simplicity, we can let \Delta = ad - bc, and then the solution becomes,
(x,y) = \brac{\frac{d}{\Delta} y_1 - \frac{b}{\Delta} y_2, \frac{a}{\Delta} y_2 - \frac{c}{\Delta} y_1}
Note that this solution only exists if \Delta \neq 0. Otherwise, we are dividing by 0.
